title: Joshua Chapter 17 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Joshua chapter 17 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Joshua Chapter 17 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Joshua Chapter 17.

questions.question: Who was the firstborn of Joseph mentioned in Joshua 17?
options: Manasseh
Ephraim
Machir
Gilead
questions.correctAnswer: Manasseh
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:1 states that Manasseh was the firstborn of Joseph.

questions.question: What inheritance did Machir receive because he was a man of war?
options: Gilead and Bashan
Shechem and Hepher
Tappuah and Michmethah
Bethshean and Ibleam
questions.correctAnswer: Gilead and Bashan
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:1 explains that Machir had Gilead and Bashan because he was a man of war.

questions.question: How many daughters did Zelophehad have?
options: Three
Four
Five
Six
questions.correctAnswer: Five
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:3 lists five daughters of Zelophehad: Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah.

questions.question: To whom did Zelophehad's daughters appeal to receive an inheritance?
options: Eleazar the priest, Joshua, and the princes
Moses alone
The elders of Israel
The people of Manasseh
questions.correctAnswer: Eleazar the priest, Joshua, and the princes
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:4 says the daughters came before Eleazar the priest, Joshua son of Nun, and the princes to ask for their inheritance.

questions.question: How many portions fell to Manasseh besides the land of Gilead and Bashan?
options: Five
Seven
Ten
Twelve
questions.correctAnswer: Ten
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:5 states that ten portions fell to Manasseh besides Gilead and Bashan.

questions.question: Which land belonged to the children of Ephraim though it was on the border of Manasseh?
options: Tappuah
Michmethah
Entappuah
Shechem
questions.correctAnswer: Tappuah
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:8 indicates that Tappuah on the border of Manasseh belonged to the children of Ephraim.

questions.question: Where did the coast of Manasseh go according to Joshua 17?
options: From Asher to Michmethah
From Gilead to Bashan
From Taanach to Megiddo
From Issachar to Ephraim
questions.correctAnswer: From Asher to Michmethah
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:7 states the coast of Manasseh was from Asher to Michmethah.

questions.question: True or False: The children of Manasseh were able to fully drive out the inhabitants of Bethshean and other cities.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:12 says the children of Manasseh could not drive out the inhabitants of those cities.

questions.question: What did the children of Israel do to the Canaanites after becoming strong?
options: Put them to tribute
Expelled them completely
Made an alliance
Ignored them
questions.correctAnswer: Put them to tribute
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:13 explains that the Israelites put the Canaanites to tribute but did not drive them out.

questions.question: What complaint did the children of Joseph make to Joshua regarding their inheritance?
options: They received only one lot and portion
Their land was too large
They had no mountains
They wanted more chariots
questions.correctAnswer: They received only one lot and portion
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:14 records the children of Joseph complaining about receiving only one lot and portion to inherit.

questions.question: What did Joshua advise the children of Joseph to do if their territory was too narrow?
options: Go to the wood country and cut down trees
Ask for more land from other tribes
Build walls around their cities
Make peace with the Perizzites
questions.correctAnswer: Go to the wood country and cut down trees
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:15 says Joshua told them to go up to the wood country and cut down trees if the mount Ephraim was too narrow.

questions.question: True or False: The Canaanites in the valley had chariots of iron.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:16 states that the Canaanites in the valley had chariots of iron.

questions.question: Which two houses of Joseph did Joshua speak to about their inheritance?
options: Ephraim and Manasseh
Machir and Gilead
Abiezer and Helek
Asriel and Shechem
questions.correctAnswer: Ephraim and Manasseh
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:17 states Joshua spoke to the house of Joseph, specifically Ephraim and Manasseh.

questions.question: True or False: Joshua promised that the children of Joseph would only receive one lot as their inheritance.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:17-18 explains that Joshua promised more than one lot and that the mountain would be theirs.

questions.question: Complete the verse: 'But the mountain shall be thine; for it is a wood, and thou shalt ______ it down.'
options: cut
build
plant
avoid
questions.correctAnswer: cut
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:18 says 'the mountain shall be thine; for it is a wood, and thou shalt cut it down.'

questions.question: Which cities and their inhabitants did Manasseh have in Issachar and Asher?
options: Bethshean, Ibleam, Dor, Endor, Taanach, Megiddo
Shechem, Hepher, Shemida, Abiezer
Michmethah, Entappuah, Tappuah, Kanah
Gilead, Bashan, Ephraim, Perizzites
questions.correctAnswer: Bethshean, Ibleam, Dor, Endor, Taanach, Megiddo
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:11 lists these cities and their inhabitants as part of Manasseh's territory.

medium.title: Joshua Chapter 17 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Joshua Chapter 17 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer feels overlooked because they have fewer resources than others. Based on Joshua 17:3-6, what biblical truth about inheritance and God's fairness can you share?
options: God honors the faithfulness of all, giving an inheritance even to daughters when there are no sons.
Only the eldest son receives an inheritance, regardless of family size.
Inheritance is based purely on worldly power and strength.
Daughters cannot receive any inheritance according to God's law.
questions.correctAnswer: God honors the faithfulness of all, giving an inheritance even to daughters when there are no sons.
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:3-6 shows that Zelophehad's daughters received an inheritance because the LORD commanded Moses to give them one, demonstrating God's fairness and care for all His people, regardless of gender or status.

questions.question: How does Joshua 17:14-15 teach us about proactive faith and responsibility when facing limited resources?
options: If resources seem limited, we should actively work to expand our opportunities by faith and effort.
We should accept our lot without complaint, even if it is insufficient.
God will always increase resources without any action on our part.
Complaining about our portion is a sign of strong faith.
questions.correctAnswer: If resources seem limited, we should actively work to expand our opportunities by faith and effort.
questions.explanation: In Joshua 17:14-15, Joshua encourages the children of Joseph to cut down the wood country if their allotted land is too small, showing that faith includes taking initiative and trusting God through action.

questions.question: A believer struggles with fear of opposition in their spiritual walk. Based on Joshua 17:16-18, what encouragement about facing strong enemies can you share?
options: Though enemies are strong, God empowers His people to overcome them through faith and obedience.
Strong enemies mean we should avoid confrontation and live in fear.
Victory depends solely on human strength and weapons.
God does not expect us to face strong opposition.
questions.correctAnswer: Though enemies are strong, God empowers His people to overcome them through faith and obedience.
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:16-18 teaches that even though Canaanites had iron chariots and were strong, God promised the land and power to drive them out, encouraging believers to trust God's strength over fear.

questions.question: What does Joshua 17:12-13 teach us about perseverance and trusting God when challenges remain in our lives?
options: Even if challenges persist, we must continue faithful service and trust God’s ultimate plan.
If problems remain, it shows God has abandoned us.
We should give up if we face ongoing difficulties.
God always removes all problems immediately for believers.
questions.correctAnswer: Even if challenges persist, we must continue faithful service and trust God’s ultimate plan.
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:12-13 shows that the children of Manasseh could not fully drive out the Canaanites but put them to tribute, demonstrating perseverance and trusting God's timing despite incomplete victories.

questions.question: How does the example of Zelophehad's daughters in Joshua 17 teach about advocating for justice and inheritance rights within the family?
options: They courageously approached leaders to claim their God-given rights, showing the importance of speaking up.
They accepted their fate quietly without seeking inheritance.
Inheritance rights should only be claimed by men.
Family disputes should never be brought before leaders.
questions.correctAnswer: They courageously approached leaders to claim their God-given rights, showing the importance of speaking up.
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:3-4 reveals that the daughters of Zelophehad came before Eleazar, Joshua, and princes to claim their inheritance as commanded by the LORD, teaching believers to seek justice respectfully and boldly.

questions.question: True or False: According to Joshua 17:5-6, the daughters of Manasseh had no inheritance among their brethren.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:6 states that the daughters of Manasseh had an inheritance among his sons, indicating that daughters did receive land among their brothers.

questions.question: True or False: Joshua encouraged the tribe of Joseph to remain content with their given land and not seek to expand into the wooded hill country.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:15-18 shows Joshua encouraging Joseph’s descendants to cut down the wood country and claim the mountain, indicating proactive faith rather than contentment with a small portion.

questions.question: How does the allocation of land in Joshua 17:7-11 teach about God's provision and order in family and community life?
options: God provides specifically for each family and tribe, encouraging unity and responsibility in stewardship.
Land was given randomly without regard to family ties.
God expected people to take land by force without order.
Provision is only given to the strongest families.
questions.correctAnswer: God provides specifically for each family and tribe, encouraging unity and responsibility in stewardship.
questions.explanation: Verses 7-11 detail how land was distributed among families and tribes with clear borders, showing God's orderly provision and the importance of stewardship within community and family.

questions.question: A believer is frustrated because their family is smaller and less influential. Based on Joshua 17:1-2, how can you encourage them regarding God's blessing and purpose?
options: God blesses according to His plan, and even smaller families have important roles and inheritances.
Only large families receive God’s blessing.
Influence depends solely on family size and power.
God’s blessings are reserved for the eldest sons.
questions.correctAnswer: God blesses according to His plan, and even smaller families have important roles and inheritances.
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:1-2 shows the tribe of Manasseh including various families, each receiving specific inheritances, indicating God’s blessing is purposeful regardless of family size.

questions.question: What does Joshua 17:8-10 teach us about cooperation and respect among neighboring tribes and communities?
options: Boundaries respected and shared lands reflect God’s design for peaceful coexistence.
Neighbors must always compete aggressively for land.
Sharing land is a sign of weakness.
Tribes should ignore borders and take what they want.
questions.correctAnswer: Boundaries respected and shared lands reflect God’s design for peaceful coexistence.
questions.explanation: Verses 8-10 describe land on borders shared and respected between Manasseh and Ephraim, teaching the value of cooperation and respect for neighbors.

questions.question: According to Joshua 17:14, how should believers respond when feeling that their portion is small despite their numbers and blessings?
options: Bring concerns respectfully before leadership and seek God’s guidance for growth.
Complain without action and harbor resentment.
Ignore the blessings and focus only on what is lacking.
Demand more without humility.
questions.correctAnswer: Bring concerns respectfully before leadership and seek God’s guidance for growth.
questions.explanation: The children of Joseph came to Joshua expressing their concern about their portion (Joshua 17:14), showing the importance of respectful communication and seeking God’s direction when facing challenges.

questions.question: A believer is overwhelmed by spiritual opposition and doubts their ability to overcome. Based on Joshua 17:18, what biblical truth about God’s empowerment can you share?
options: God empowers believers to overcome even strong opposition when they obey and persevere.
Opposition proves God’s absence.
Believers must rely solely on their own strength to win.
Strong enemies mean God has rejected us.
questions.correctAnswer: God empowers believers to overcome even strong opposition when they obey and persevere.
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:18 encourages the house of Joseph that despite iron chariots and strong enemies, God’s people will drive them out, showing God’s power over adversity.

questions.question: How does Joshua 17:11 teach about stewardship and responsibility toward the land God has given?
options: Believers are responsible for occupying and caring for the land God grants them, including towns and cities.
The land will take care of itself without human effort.
Stewardship is optional for believers.
Land ownership is only symbolic with no practical duties.
questions.correctAnswer: Believers are responsible for occupying and caring for the land God grants them, including towns and cities.
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:11 lists towns and regions under Manasseh’s control, indicating the importance of taking responsibility for the land God provides.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Joshua 17:17 says, 'Thou art a great people, and hast great power: thou shalt not have ________ lot only.'
options: one
two
three
no
questions.correctAnswer: one
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:17 encourages the house of Joseph that because they are great and powerful, they shall not have one lot only, implying more inheritance will be granted.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with contentment regarding their spiritual gifts and opportunities. How does Joshua 17:15-18 encourage a biblical attitude toward growth and effort?
options: We should work diligently and courageously to expand what God has given us, trusting His blessing.
We should be passive and accept only what we have.
Growth happens without any effort on our part.
We should envy others instead of working ourselves.
questions.correctAnswer: We should work diligently and courageously to expand what God has given us, trusting His blessing.
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:15-18 shows Joshua encouraging the tribe of Joseph to cut down the wood and claim more land, illustrating the biblical value of diligence and faith in God’s provision.

hard.title: Joshua Chapter 17 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Joshua Chapter 17.

questions.question: Who was given the land of Gilead and Bashan because he was a man of war?
options: Machir the firstborn of Manasseh
Zelophehad
Joshua the son of Nun
Eleazar the priest
questions.correctAnswer: Machir the firstborn of Manasseh
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:1 states that Machir, the firstborn of Manasseh, was given Gilead and Bashan because he was a man of war.

questions.question: Which of the following families was NOT mentioned as part of the children of Manasseh in their families?
options: Children of Abiezer
Children of Helek
Children of Gad
Children of Shemida
questions.correctAnswer: Children of Gad
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:2 lists families of Manasseh but does not mention Gad, who is a separate tribe.

questions.question: What was unique about Zelophehad's descendants in relation to inheritance?
options: He had only daughters
He had many sons
He had no children
He was a priest
questions.correctAnswer: He had only daughters
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:3 notes that Zelophehad had no sons but daughters, which was significant for inheritance rights.

questions.question: What command from the LORD did the daughters of Zelophehad invoke to claim their inheritance?
options: The LORD commanded Moses to give them an inheritance among their brethren
The LORD commanded Joshua to divide the land equally
The LORD commanded Eleazar to bless the land
The LORD commanded the children of Israel to conquer Canaan
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD commanded Moses to give them an inheritance among their brethren
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:4 explains that the daughters cited the LORD's command to Moses giving them inheritance among their brethren.

questions.question: How many portions fell to the tribe of Manasseh besides the land of Gilead and Bashan?
options: Ten
Five
Twelve
Seven
questions.correctAnswer: Ten
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:5 states that ten portions fell to Manasseh besides Gilead and Bashan.

questions.question: The border of Manasseh extended from which tribe to Michmethah before Shechem?
options: Asher
Ephraim
Issachar
Naphtali
questions.correctAnswer: Asher
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:7 describes Manasseh's border as from Asher to Michmethah before Shechem.

questions.question: Which city did Manasseh have that also belonged to the children of Ephraim on the border?
options: Tappuah
Bethshean
Megiddo
Dor
questions.correctAnswer: Tappuah
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:8 clarifies that Manasseh had Tappuah, but it belonged to Ephraim on the border.

questions.question: True or False: The children of Manasseh fully drove out the inhabitants of the cities in Issachar and Asher.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:12 says the children of Manasseh could not drive out the inhabitants, and the Canaanites lived there.

questions.question: What reason did the children of Joseph give for being dissatisfied with their inheritance?
options: They were a great people blessed by the LORD
They wanted more priests
They lacked water sources
They wanted to settle outside Canaan
questions.correctAnswer: They were a great people blessed by the LORD
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:14 records their complaint that despite being a great, blessed people, they received only one lot.

questions.question: Joshua instructed the children of Joseph to go to what kind of land if mount Ephraim was too narrow?
options: The wood country
The desert
The plains
The river valley
questions.correctAnswer: The wood country
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:15 tells them to go to the wood country and cut down trees if mount Ephraim was too narrow.

questions.question: Which military advantage did the Canaanites in the valley have that concerned the children of Joseph?
options: Chariots of iron
Archers on high ground
Elephants
Fortified walls
questions.correctAnswer: Chariots of iron
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:16 highlights the Canaanites' iron chariots as a concern for the children of Joseph.

questions.question: How did Joshua describe the power and population of the house of Joseph?
options: A great people with great power
A small tribe with little power
A priestly family
A wandering nomadic group
questions.correctAnswer: A great people with great power
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:17 states that Joshua acknowledged them as a great people with great power.

questions.question: What was Joshua’s promise about the mountain land to the house of Joseph?
options: The mountain shall be thine, and thou shalt cut it down
The mountain shall be given to the priests only
The mountain shall remain uncultivated
The mountain shall be a city of refuge
questions.correctAnswer: The mountain shall be thine, and thou shalt cut it down
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:18 promises that the mountain land is theirs to clear and possess despite the strong Canaanites.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: The daughters of Zelophehad were named Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, _____, and Tirzah.
options: Milcah
Miriam
Mahalath
Martha
questions.correctAnswer: Milcah
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:3 lists the daughters of Zelophehad as Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah.

questions.question: Which priest was present when the daughters of Zelophehad came to claim their inheritance?
options: Eleazar
Aaron
Phinehas
Zadok
questions.correctAnswer: Eleazar
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:4 mentions Eleazar the priest was present when the daughters approached for inheritance.

theological.title: Joshua Chapter 17 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Joshua Chapter 17 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Joshua 17:3-4, what was the significance of Zelophehad's daughters requesting an inheritance?
options: They represented the fulfillment of God's command regarding inheritance rights for daughters in the absence of sons.
They sought to expand Manasseh's territorial boundaries beyond the Jordan River.
They requested special priestly privileges for their family.
They wanted to establish a new tribe separate from Manasseh.
questions.correctAnswer: They represented the fulfillment of God's command regarding inheritance rights for daughters in the absence of sons.
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:3-4 shows that Zelophehad’s daughters requested their inheritance as per the LORD's command to Moses, which aligns with God's justice in Numbers 27:1-11 and supports inheritance rights in Deuteronomy 21:15-17. This reflects God's equitable treatment of heirs when no sons are present, consistent with biblical principles of justice in inheritance.

questions.question: In Joshua 17:6, what theological principle is illustrated by the daughters of Manasseh receiving an inheritance among the sons?
options: God’s justice extends beyond traditional patriarchal customs to uphold fairness.
Only sons are entitled to inherit land and blessings.
Inheritance is based solely on military conquest.
Daughters cannot inherit land under any circumstances.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s justice extends beyond traditional patriarchal customs to uphold fairness.
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:6 highlights that the daughters of Manasseh received an inheritance, demonstrating God's justice and fairness that transcends cultural norms, consistent with Numbers 27:7 and Galatians 3:28, where God values all equally regardless of gender.

questions.question: What does Joshua 17:12-13 reveal about the spiritual and practical challenges faced by Israel in possessing the land?
options: The Israelites struggled to fully drive out the Canaanites and only subdued them to tribute.
The Israelites easily conquered all inhabitants without any resistance.
The Canaanites voluntarily vacated the land.
God abandoned Israel to the Canaanites due to their disobedience.
questions.correctAnswer: The Israelites struggled to fully drive out the Canaanites and only subdued them to tribute.
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:12-13 explains Israel’s incomplete conquest, illustrating the ongoing spiritual battle and human failure to fully obey God’s command, paralleling Judges 1:27-36 and emphasizing the need for God's empowerment in spiritual warfare (Ephesians 6:10-12).

questions.question: What is the significance of Joshua’s instruction in Joshua 17:15-18 regarding the 'wood country' and cutting down trees?
options: It symbolizes active faith and perseverance in overcoming obstacles despite strong enemies.
It means the Israelites should abandon their inheritance claims.
It instructs the Israelites to avoid conflict with the giants and Perizzites.
It encourages settling only in fertile plains, avoiding mountainous regions.
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes active faith and perseverance in overcoming obstacles despite strong enemies.
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:15-18 illustrates the call to active faith and courage to claim God’s promises, even when faced with daunting enemies, echoing themes in Deuteronomy 1:30-31 and Hebrews 11:32-34 about trusting God’s power to overcome giants and obstacles.

questions.question: How does Joshua 17:1-2 establish the tribe of Manasseh's role in God's redemptive plan?
options: Manasseh, as Joseph’s firstborn, receives a significant allotment emphasizing God’s blessing and faithfulness.
Manasseh is excluded from receiving any land inheritance.
Manasseh is commanded to be a priestly tribe.
Manasseh is identified as a tribe destined for exile.
questions.correctAnswer: Manasseh, as Joseph’s firstborn, receives a significant allotment emphasizing God’s blessing and faithfulness.
questions.explanation: Verses 1-2 show God's faithfulness in blessing Joseph's descendants through Manasseh with a prominent inheritance, reflecting covenant fulfillment seen in Genesis 48:17-20 and Psalm 105:8-11 regarding God's enduring promises to Abraham’s seed.

questions.question: What does the mixed possession of land between Ephraim and Manasseh in Joshua 17:8-10 teach about God's providence and human cooperation?
options: God’s providence allows overlapping boundaries, requiring cooperation between tribes.
God strictly separates tribal boundaries with no overlap.
Each tribe is to conquer land without regard for others.
Human conflict is inevitable due to God’s neglect.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s providence allows overlapping boundaries, requiring cooperation between tribes.
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:8-10 shows intertwined territories of Ephraim and Manasseh, reflecting God’s providential design that necessitates unity and cooperation, consistent with themes in 1 Corinthians 12:12-27 about the body of Christ and communal harmony.

questions.question: In light of Joshua 17:14, what theological principle can be drawn from the children of Joseph’s complaint about their inheritance?
options: God’s blessings come with responsibility and require faith to claim them fully.
God’s blessings are always immediately and fully realized without effort.
Inheritance is guaranteed without any limitations or challenges.
Complaining about God’s provision is always justified.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s blessings come with responsibility and require faith to claim them fully.
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:14 reveals Israel’s awareness of blessing yet challenges in claiming it, teaching that God’s gifts require active faith and perseverance, resonating with James 2:17 and Philippians 2:12-13 about working out salvation with fear and trembling.

questions.question: How does the presence of iron chariots among the Canaanites in Joshua 17:16 reflect on the spiritual and physical challenges Israel faced?
options: It symbolizes formidable opposition that requires reliance on God's power, not human strength.
It shows that Israel had superior military technology.
It indicates the Canaanites were weak and easy to defeat.
It means Israel should avoid confrontation altogether.
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes formidable opposition that requires reliance on God's power, not human strength.
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:16’s mention of iron chariots highlights daunting opposition, teaching that victory depends on God’s strength as in 2 Chronicles 14:11 and Psalm 20:7, not on human weaponry or might alone.

questions.question: What eschatological hope is implicit in Joshua 17:18’s promise that the children of Joseph will drive out strong enemies despite iron chariots?
options: God’s ultimate victory over evil is assured despite present difficulties.
Human effort alone will bring final peace.
Enemies will always remain undefeated.
God has abandoned His people in battle.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s ultimate victory over evil is assured despite present difficulties.
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:18 promises victory over strong foes, symbolizing the eschatological assurance of God’s triumph over evil, paralleling Revelation 19:11-21 and Romans 8:37 where believers overcome through Christ's power.

questions.question: What does the division of land described in Joshua 17:5 teach about God's covenant faithfulness?
options: God faithfully fulfills His promises to give the land to the tribes of Israel.
God withholds the land from the firstborn tribes.
The land is given based on human merit alone.
God’s promises are conditional upon total conquest without exception.
questions.correctAnswer: God faithfully fulfills His promises to give the land to the tribes of Israel.
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:5 records the allotment of land to Manasseh, demonstrating God’s covenant faithfulness as first promised to Abraham (Genesis 15:18-21), reaffirmed through Moses (Deuteronomy 1:8), and fulfilled in Joshua’s leadership.

questions.question: How does Joshua 17:7’s description of Manasseh’s borders contribute to our understanding of God’s providential ordering of His people?
options: God providentially assigns each tribe a distinct territory with defined borders.
Tribal borders are arbitrary and unimportant.
God intends for tribes to fight over land constantly.
Borders are assigned based on the amount of wealth each tribe has.
questions.correctAnswer: God providentially assigns each tribe a distinct territory with defined borders.
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:7’s description of borders reflects God’s sovereign ordering of His people, consistent with biblical themes of order and covenant blessings in Ezekiel 48:1-29 and Acts 17:26 about nations and boundaries.

questions.question: What role does the priest Eleazar play in the inheritance process according to Joshua 17:4?
options: Eleazar confirms and administers the LORD’s command regarding inheritance.
Eleazar leads the military conquest of the land.
Eleazar opposes the daughters receiving inheritance.
Eleazar designates new tribal leaders.
questions.correctAnswer: Eleazar confirms and administers the LORD’s command regarding inheritance.
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:4 shows Eleazar the priest’s role in confirming inheritance according to the LORD’s command, emphasizing the priesthood’s mediatory role in upholding divine law, as seen in Numbers 36:2-7 and Hebrews 7:23-28.

questions.question: According to Joshua 17:11, which regions did the tribe of Manasseh possess, and what theological implication does this have about God’s promise?
options: Manasseh held towns in Issachar and Asher, demonstrating the extent of God’s blessing and fulfillment of the territorial promise.
Manasseh held no towns, indicating God's displeasure.
Manasseh was only given wilderness areas, symbolizing hardship.
Manasseh was exiled from the Promised Land.
questions.correctAnswer: Manasseh held towns in Issachar and Asher, demonstrating the extent of God’s blessing and fulfillment of the territorial promise.
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:11 records Manasseh’s possession of towns in Issachar and Asher, illustrating God’s expansive blessing and covenant faithfulness, consistent with Genesis 28:13-15 and Psalm 105:10-11.

questions.question: What doctrinal truth about human effort and divine enablement is emphasized in Joshua 17:18’s command to cut down the wood and drive out the Canaanites?
options: God calls for human initiative empowered by divine strength to possess His promises.
Human effort alone guarantees success without God’s help.
Divine enablement renders human effort unnecessary.
Possession of promises is automatic and requires no effort.
questions.correctAnswer: God calls for human initiative empowered by divine strength to possess His promises.
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:18 teaches cooperation between human effort and reliance on God’s power, paralleling Philippians 2:12-13 and Exodus 14:15-16, showing God’s empowerment enables the believer to act obediently and victoriously.

questions.question: How does Joshua 17:14-15 address the issue of God's blessings and human faith in the face of apparent limitations?
options: It challenges believers to actively claim God’s promises despite perceived obstacles.
It suggests believers should accept limitations without contest.
It teaches that God’s blessings are limited and finite.
It discourages believers from seeking more than what they have.
questions.correctAnswer: It challenges believers to actively claim God’s promises despite perceived obstacles.
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:14-15 records the children of Joseph complaining about limited inheritance, to which Joshua encourages proactive faith to claim what God has promised, consistent with Hebrews 11:6 and 2 Corinthians 5:7 about walking by faith, not by sight.

questions.question: What does Joshua 17:17 reveal about the identity and power of the house of Joseph?
options: They are recognized as a great and powerful people, capable of expanding their inheritance.
They are a small and insignificant group with little power.
They are forbidden from claiming additional land.
They are destined to remain in servitude to other tribes.
questions.correctAnswer: They are recognized as a great and powerful people, capable of expanding their inheritance.
questions.explanation: Joshua 17:17 affirms the house of Joseph’s greatness and power, encouraging confidence in God’s blessings, paralleling Genesis 49:22-26 and Psalm 44:3 which testify to God's empowerment and blessing on His people.
